title: 111_hr6239
content: The Act may be cited as the "Prevention of Frivolous Ethanol Lawsuits Act of 2010". It includes findings related to ethanol lawsuits. The Congress finds that ethanol is widely used in gasoline for vehicles and engines, and increasing the blending limit requires ensuring it won't harm emission control devices. Increasing the blending limit of ethanol in gasoline for vehicles and engines raises concerns about potential negative effects on engine performance and consumer complaints. The Federal Trade Commission is proposing labeling requirements for fuels with ethanol levels exceeding the current limit in gasoline to warn consumers of potential harm to conventional vehicles. Federal testing is ongoing to assess the impact on newer motor vehicles. The executive branch has statutory authority to increase the current blending limit of ethanol into gasoline, but there is insufficient data on the effects on older vehicles and nonroad engines. Federal testing is being conducted on newer motor vehicles to determine the impact of increasing the blending limit of ethanol into gasoline. The executive branch has the authority to increase the blending limit of ethanol in gasoline for older vehicles and nonroad engines. Congress should address any negative impacts on interstate commerce from this decision. Targeted liability protections are provided for claims related to damages caused by the inclusion of ethanol in certain fuel. Liability protections are granted to covered entities using renewable fuel with ethanol concentrations over 10%, for operating internal combustion engines, immune from suit and liability under Federal and State law. The term "loss" in this section includes death, injury, illness, disability, property damage, and business interruption. The immunity under paragraph (1) applies to any claim for loss related to physical, mental, emotional injury, illness, disability, property damage, or business interruption caused by the use of renewable fuel. The immunity under paragraph (1) applies to any claim for loss related to the use of renewable fuel containing ethanol in concentrations greater than 10 percent, for operating an internal combustion engine. The combustion engine's relationship with the design, development, testing, manufacture, distribution, marketing, and use of renewable fuel is subject to immunity from liability, except for cases of death or serious injury caused by willful actions. The exception to immunity from suit and liability for covered persons is for a Federal cause of action for death or serious physical injury caused by willful misconduct. This cause of action is not considered a violation of a statute of the United States. An action under 28, United States Code allows for suits for wrongful death or serious physical injury, to be filed exclusively in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Procedures for filing a suit under 28, United States Code include exclusive federal jurisdiction in the District of Columbia, governing law based on where the misconduct occurred, and pleading with particularity. In an action under subsection (b), the complaint must plead each element of the plaintiff's claim with particularity, including the alleged willful misconduct, its causation of injury, and supporting facts. The complaint in an action under subsection (b) must include specific details such as the alleged willful misconduct causing injury, facts supporting the injury claim, and verification by affidavit of the plaintiff. The plaintiff must verify the pleading by affidavit under oath, confirming its truth except for matters alleged on information and belief. Any matter not specifically identified as such shall be considered true for all purposes. The plaintiff must verify the pleading by affidavit under oath, confirming its truth except for matters alleged on information and belief. Any matter not specifically identified as such shall be considered true for all purposes, including a criminal prosecution. In an action under subsection (b), the plaintiff has the burden of proving willful misconduct by each covered person sued, with the case initially assigned to a three-judge court. The plaintiff must prove willful misconduct by each covered person sued in an action under subsection (b), assigned to a three-judge court. The panel of judges has jurisdiction over motions and may refer the action to the chief judge for further proceedings, including trial. In actions under subsection (b), the panel of judges may refer the case to the chief judge for further proceedings if motions have expired. Civil discovery is not allowed before each defendant has a chance to file a motion to dismiss. In actions under subsection (b), discovery shall be allowed before each covered person sued has had a reasonable opportunity to file a motion to dismiss, before the court has ruled on such motion, and before the Court of Appeals has ruled on an interlocutory appeal. The court shall permit discovery only with respect to matters directly related to contested material issues. In actions under subsection (b), discovery is allowed before the Court of Appeals has ruled on an interlocutory appeal. The court permits discovery only on matters directly related to contested material issues. Discovery requests are compelled only if the information is needed to prove or defend a material issue in the action. In actions under subsection (b), discovery is allowed before the Court of Appeals has ruled on an interlocutory appeal. Discovery requests are compelled under rule 37, Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, if the information is necessary to prove or defend a material issue in the action. Damages awarded to a plaintiff in such actions may be reduced by the amount of collateral source benefits received. In actions under subsection (b), damages awarded to a plaintiff may be reduced by the amount of collateral source benefits received. Noneconomic damages can only be awarded in proportion to the defendant's responsibility for harm, covering physical and emotional pain, suffering, inconvenience, physical impairment, and mental anguish. In actions under subsection (b), damages awarded to a plaintiff may be reduced by collateral source benefits. Noneconomic damages are for physical and emotional pain, suffering, inconvenience, physical impairment, mental anguish, disfigurement, loss of enjoyment of life, and other nonpecuniary losses. Rule 11 sanctions apply for violations in actions under subsection (b). Rule 11 sanctions apply in cases under subsection (b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, allowing courts to impose appropriate sanctions on attorneys or parties responsible for violations to deter future misconduct. Sanctions may include payment of expenses and attorney's fees incurred due to the violation. Rule 11 sanctions can include payment of expenses and attorney's fees for violations to deter future misconduct. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has jurisdiction over interlocutory appeals within 30 days of an order denying immunity from suit. The District of Columbia Circuit has jurisdiction over interlocutory appeals within 30 days of an order denying immunity from suit based on subsection (a) or (h)(1) exclusion for regulated activity of manufacturer or distributor. If a manufacturer or distributor's act or omission related to a covered countermeasure is regulated by the Clean Air Act and not subject to enforcement action by the EPA or Attorney General, it shall not be considered willful misconduct under subsection (b). The Clean Air Act states that if a manufacturer or distributor's act related to a covered countermeasure is not subject to enforcement action by the EPA or Attorney General, it is not considered willful misconduct. Any action under this section is stayed during the pendency of an enforcement action. Nothing in this section limits the rights or remedies of the United States or its agencies. During an enforcement action, actions by and against the United States are not limited by this section, preserving rights, remedies, and sovereign immunity. Definitions in this section include "covered entity" as a term for entities affected by the regulations. In this section, definitions include "covered entity" as an entity involved in the fuel or renewable fuel industry. Enforcement action refers to various legal actions such as criminal prosecution, injunctions, seizures, civil monetary proceedings, mandatory recalls, product repairs, debarment, and investigator disqualifications. Covered remedy includes outcomes like criminal convictions and injunctions. In an investigator disqualification proceeding, a covered remedy refers to outcomes like criminal convictions, injunctions, civil monetary payments, and debarment resulting from a final court determination or agency action. The term "final" refers to a judgment from which an appeal of right cannot be taken or a voluntary dismissal in a court determination, and an order that is not subject to further review within the agency in an agency action. The term "willful misconduct" under subsection (b) does not include actions taken in compliance with regulations or guidance issued in response to an agency action. The term "willful misconduct" under subsection (b) excludes actions taken in compliance with regulations or guidance issued in response to a waiver of Clean Air Act requirements for ethanol-gasoline blends over 10% ethanol by volume. It refers to actions intentionally taken to achieve a wrongful purpose. The term "willful misconduct" excludes actions taken in compliance with regulations for ethanol-gasoline blends over 10% ethanol by volume. It denotes intentional acts to achieve a wrongful purpose, knowingly without legal justification, and in disregard of a known risk.
